newsitem.title: MONTSERRAT: Montserratians warned away from abandoned capital.
newsitem.headline: Montserratians warned away from abandoned capital.

text.p: Authorities on Tuesday warned residents to steer clear of Montserrat's abandoned capital, Plymouth, as ash, gas and hot rock spewed from the Soufriere Hills volcano.
Plymouth was evacuated 14 months ago and lies under a heavy coating of ash, but residents frequently return to dust off roofs and check on homes and businesses.
Scientists at the Montserrat Volcano Observatory said ash clouds could be seen rising from the Gage Valley area and rockfalls were spotted in other valleys flanking the volcano.
"The authorities and MVO advise that nobody go into Plymouth for the time being," a government statement said.
The volcano has been active in recent weeks, with "pyroclastic flows" of superheated rock and gases spilling from the mountain into surrounding valleys.

The capital sits on the rumbling mountain's western flank. Some 4,000 residents of Plymouth and the island's south end were evacuated to northern "safe zones" in April 1996. The Soufriere Hills volcano roared to life in July 1995, after nearly four centuries of virtual dormancy.
Montserrat is a British colony in the eastern Caribbean, about 25 miles (40 km) southwest of Antigua.
